Phy mode of a TOM.
The configured, negotiated, or actual speed.
Link is currently disconnected or initializing.
Full duplex.
Half duplex.
The configured, negotiated, or actual duplex mode.
Link is currently disconnected or initializing.
No pause frames are supported.
Symmetric flow (transmit and receive).
Transmit direction only.
Receive direction only.
The configured, negotiated, or actual flow-control mode.
Possible baud-rates for a serial console port.
Card category.
Refers to line-side 'colored' CWDM or DWDM optical module/transceiver.
Refers to standard 'grey' interfaces/transceivers to interface with other client equipment.
USB port.
Communication ports.
Refers to ports of an aggregation function that connect to an adjunct line function.
Same as tributary, but for scenarios where the main tributary port is split into multiple subports.
General optical port, with or without monitoring function.
Generic OTDR function, except for external OTDR measurement.
Port function represents the L0 module cage for pluggable interfaces.
OCM port.
The port type. Each port type supports different features and services.
Not applicable.
Tx direction.
Rx direction.
Both Rx and Tx directions.
Direction of the port.
Maximum power draw for this card.
Common parameters to all equipment objects.
User defined alias for this entity. Must be an alphanumeric string with dash or underscore.
Attributes associated with all equipment holders (slots and ports).
List of supported types in this equipment holder. If a specific type is provisioned, the list has only that type.
Currently installed type in this equipment holder. If empty, means no FRU is present.
Inventory data for equipment that are not yet accepted by the node controller in a Multi-chassis NE. This is a reduced set derived from the inventory container
Hardware version of this FRU.
FRU type of actual equipment.
FRU subtype of actual equipment - only available if applicable.
Current PON of the equipment.
Serial number of the equipment.
Common Language Equipment Identifier.
Vendor of this equipment.
Part number for this equipment.
Manufacture Date in a date-time format (YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ) or 'NA' if not available.
Inventory data for a present FRU.
Insertion Date in a date-time format (YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ) or 'NA' if not available.
When applicatible, provides number of supported optical lanes in this equipment.
Vendor Compliance Code information for 3rd party TOMs.
Card doesn't have upgradable firmware.
All components have current firmware.
At least one component does not have current firmare.
Information on all firmware status is currently unavailable.
Summary status for all the firmware for this card.
List of current firmware available in the card.
Name of the firmware.
Current version of the firmware.
Expected version of the firmware.
Current firmware is up-to-date.
Current firmware is not up-to-date against the expected one.
Information on firmware status is currently unavailable.
Status for this particular firmware.
Slot equipment holder details.
Slot name.
Name of the equipment that is currently required in this slot.
Existing slots and respective information about them. This grouping represents a general slot.
Upgrade status not available.
Upgrade install is in progress.
Upgrade installed.
Upgrade instalation failed.
Upgrade status not known.
Current upgrade status.
Container for all equipment related resources.
Chassis configuration and state.
Chassis name.
Tells if this chassis the node controller of this NE.
Chassis role is not determined yet
The chassis is designated as a main-chassis of the Multi-chassis NE.
The chassis is designated as a sub-chassis of the Multi-chassis NE.
Identifies the role of the chassis in a multi-chassis NE.
Inform the NC the serial number of a sub-chassis. For the main-chassis, the value is auto-filled with its own serial number
Chassis type.
The subtype of the chassis
User defined location
User defined rack name (withing the location)
Position of the chassis within the rack.
DC PEM
High-line (220V) AC PEM
Low-line (110V) AC PEM
High Voltage DC PEM
Defines what is the expected type of PEMs that this chassis will have. It is not possible to configure each PEM slot individually, as all PEMs need to be of the same type.
Standard FAN type.
Counter rotating FAN type.
Defines what is the expected type of FANs that this chassis will have. It is not possible to configure each FAN slot individually, this needs to be done at the chassis level.
Under voltage threshold on PEM input feed.
Over voltage threshold on PEM input feed.
Available Power at the chassis based on the current provisioned equipment.

User configured limit of power usable by this chassis. If current-estimated-power-draw used in this chassis goes above the configured-max-power-draw, the alarm PWRDRAW is raised. 10000W represents a 'very high' power draw that is beyond any chassis possibilities, so having this value means this feature is disabled, and the alarm is never raised.
Total estimated power of both installed and pre-provisioned FRUs
Configured ambient temperature for the chassis, used to compute the FRU's power consumption.
PEM is redundant within a bank of 2 PEMs.
PEM is redundant against any other PEM.
Configuration of the PEM redundancy mode.
No switch over
Switch over possible
If enabled, the standby controller will be locked out from taking over the active card. This means no manual or autonomous switchovers will happen.
Identifies the active controller slot name. A change to this attribute implies a switchover has happened.

Represents the equipment discovery state for the current chassis. It will remain as 'false' until all equipment was discovered during startup. Equipment added after startup will not contribute to the update of this state.

Represents the alarm monitoring state for this chassis. After a system restart, alarms are kept persistent for a grace minute period, after which they will be cleared, unless they are reconfirmed. This state provides visibility whether that grace period has passed or not. When this state is true, there are no more cached alarms raised.
Card base object.This object has parameters that are common to all existing card types (controller, fan, etc).
Card identifier.
Required card type.
The subtype of the card
The configured card-mode, identifies specific card functionality.
Chassis where this card is located.
Slot where this card is located.
Subslot where this card is located, e.g. 1-2.3 (slot 2, subslot 3). 'subslot-name' can only be set on (sub)card creation.
User configured power draw for this card.
Reason why the last reboot was done.
Timestamp of the last reboot event of a card.
Name of the parent card, only applicable for subcard(s).
List of sub-cards associated with this card. Only applicable for carrier cards.
Container of parameters related with controller cards.
Controller state.
Standby controller is sync and ready.
Standby controller synchronizing data with active controller.
Synchronization fail.
Protection in lock-out state.
Standby card is not present
State of the controller redundancy.
Number of times that an active controller card has switchover. Value only visibile on active controller card.
Timestamp of the last controller switchover event. Value only visible on active controller card.
Additional details for synchronization status.
Generic card port.
Port name.
Name of the parent port. Only applicable for sub-ports.
List of sub-ports associated with this port. Only applicable when this port is a parent port.
Top level interface hosted in this port.

Indicate neighbour port entity to which the current port is connected to. This is not validated by the NE and can be used by the customers (or NMS) for topology construction. This parameter is available independently on any automated discovery mechanisms that may exist in the port.
Port has no NMS external connectivity.
Port has NMS external connectivity.
Indicates whether the port is connected or to be connected externally or not.
TOM (Transceiver Optical Module) pluggable information.
The type of the TOM.
The subtype of the TOM.
Configured Phy Mode.
List of supported Phy Modes by this TOM type.
Used to override the power class for 3rd party TOM.
Controls enabling/disabling of configuring TOM SerDes.
The user configured (or overridden) set of serializer/desserializer.
Represents the USB function of this port.
USB port can be used for file storage, and supports associated file management operations.
USB port can be used to power additional external equipment (for example, passive shelves).
The role that this usb port has.
Describes the presence state of the USB connector.
The current available storage space in the file-system associated with this USB port.
The total storage space available in the file-system associated with this USB port.
Local filesystem path on where this USB file-system is mounted; this can be used as a target/source for file transfer operations.
Communication ethernet port.
Auto negotiation mode.
The maximum transmission unit size in octets for the physical Ethernet port.
Duplex mode; only valid if auto-negotiation is disabled.
Operational duplex mode.
Required Ethernet rate; only valid if auto-negotiation is disabled.
Operational Ethernet rate.
Specifies the type of flow control to be supported.
Operational flow control.
No redundancy.
Port is active.
Port is on standby.
Redundancy state of the comm port.
MAC Address of the port.
Parameters associated with this card's serial console port.

System will auto-detect the baud-rate based on 'ENTER' presses on serial console client side. The detected baud-rate is then locked, and shown in the 'actual-baudrate' parameter. Note: not all cards support auto-sensing capability.
The configured baud-rate for this card's console port. Default value is card type specific.
The actual baud-rate for this card's console port. If auto-sensing is enabled, this will reveal the detected baud-rate. If a fixed baud-rate is configured, this will match the configured baud-rate.
Represents that the auto-sensing algorithm is active, waiting for 'ENTER' presses on serial console client side.

Auto-sensing algorithm already discovered the port's baud-rate (visible in the actual-baud-rate parameter), and has locked that value. No further auto-sensing is performed until baud-rate is reconfigured or card reboots.
Current state of the auto-sensing mechanism. Only visible if auto-sensing is enabled for this port.
Console switch is using the global switch configuration.
Console switch is enabled.
Console switch is disabled.
Defines the global access to all card's console port. Access can be overridden per console port at the card level.
Current status of the console for this card.
Container of all equipment LEDs.
Representation of a LED in a FRU. Object exists even if FRU is not physically present.
AID of equipment location of the LED (may be a chassis, card or a port AID).
Name of the LED within the FRU.
LED status not available.
LED is turned off and has no color.
LED is turned on with yellow color.
LED is flashing, alternating between off and yellow color.
LED is turned on with green color.
LED is flashing, alternating between off and green color.
LED is turned on with red color.
LED is flashing, alternating between off and red color.
LED is cycling between all supported colors, including off state.
LED is cycling between all supported colors (excluding off state) - used for lamp test.
LED is turned on with amber color.
LED is flashing, alternating between off and amber color.
Current color status of the LED.
Container with all existing equipment policies.

Enables automatic update of tom subtype based on present equipment. This update may have direct impact on existing configurations. Note: this has impact on tom subtype migration, but not for tom type migration (e.g. no update between QSFPDD and QSFP28).
Manual mode where sub-chassis ID is assigned either via user configuration or ZTP mechanism.
Determine if the chassis id assignment is done manually or automatically.
The DCN port is at the front of the chassis. Depending on the chassis type, may imply that the CRAFT port is at the back.
The DCN port is at the back of the chassis. If the chassis supports this option, implies that the CRAFT port is at the front.
Physical location of the communication ethernet ports.
Container for templates associated with equipment.

Whether serdes-templates are globally enabled or not. See description of 'serdes-template' list for details. On enabling: templates are not automatically applies; they'll be applied from that moment onward. On disabling: no impact; existing serdes configuration is kept on all TOMs, independently on whether they were applied via template or manually.

A template that allows to auto-configure serdes for 3rd party TOMs. serdes-templates are created by the user per tom-part-number and apply to all line cards that support serdes; when a TOM is plugged-in with that part-number, the template will be automatically applied. User can narrow down the list of ports to which the template applies, but by default all ports are considered. Manual configuration of serdes can still be done, and will be kept even if it deviates from the template. Switching a TOM with another TOM with a different part-number will imply a reset of the serdes configuration, and re-apply of the new template (if existing). Application of serdes-templates is dependent on the use-serdes-templates flag being set to 'true'. User can force the re-application of a serdes-template by using the 'apply-template' command.
The TOM part-number to which this template applies.
The list of ports to which this template is applicable, or 'all' if all ports are to be considered (default).
An individual entry to the serdes-template, composed of a serdes parameter name and associated value.
Name of the serdes parameter.
Value of the serdes parameter.

Allows configuration of the power profile used for all instances of a given card type, if that card supports power-profiles. Alternatively, the global-power-profile can be disabled, which means each card instance will have its own power profile individually configurable. Changing the global-power-profile will have impact on both existing card instances, as well as newly created card instances. Power profiles are a way to categorize the power estimation for the system.
The card-type associated with this global-power-profile configuration.

Whether this global-power-profile is enabled. If enabled, both existing and newly created instances of card-type will have its power-profile set to the selected global value. If disabled, each card instance has the ability to configure its own power-profile. The enabling of the global profile is only allowed if all chassis have enough available-power.

Globally used profile-name for this card-type, if enabled. Needs to match an existing supported-power-profile name for this card. Attribute has no impact if global profile is not enabled. The changing of the global profile is only allowed if all chassis have enough available-power.
List of detected inventory but not yet accepted by the Node Controller in Multi-Chassis configuration.
The residing chassis serial number.
The residing slot name for the equipment. If the equipment is the chassis, the slot-name is empty
Timestamp with the last time the unprovisioned equipment was detected by the Node Controller.
